title: 103_hr4535
content: SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. The Act is titled the "Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994" and it amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to allow national securities exchanges to extend unlisted trading privileges to certain securities. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows national securities exchanges to extend unlisted trading privileges to certain securities, with regulations set by the Commission for fair and orderly markets and investor protection. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows national securities exchanges to extend trading intervals for newly listed securities, with additional procedures set by the Commission for market fairness and investor protection. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows national securities exchanges to extend trading intervals for newly listed securities. The Commission must ensure that such extensions are in line with market fairness, investor protection, and the development of a national market system. National securities exchanges cannot extend unlisted trading privileges if it unreasonably impairs their rules. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows national securities exchanges to extend trading intervals for newly listed securities. Exchanges must ensure that such extensions do not unreasonably impair dealers' ability to solicit transactions or restrict competition among dealers. Exchanges can only continue unlisted trading privileges if they meet eligibility requirements, except for securities listed before July 1, 1964. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows exchanges to extend trading intervals for newly listed securities. If trading privileges are discontinued, the exchange must cease trading in that security unless requirements are met. An initial public offering of a security is defined by specific criteria under this act. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows the Commission to suspend unlisted trading privileges on an exchange within 60 days of commencement of trading. The exchange must cease trading in the security upon suspension, as prescribed by the Commission for market fairness and investor protection. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows the Commission to suspend trading privileges on an exchange if necessary for market fairness and investor protection. The exchange must file an application to reinstate its ability to extend unlisted trading privileges, which remains in effect until approved by the Commission. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows the securities exchange to apply for reinstatement of unlisted trading privileges, subject to Commission approval based on market fairness, investor protection, and national market system development. The Unlisted Trading Privileges Act of 1994 allows securities exchanges to apply for reinstatement of unlisted trading privileges, subject to Commission approval based on market fairness, investor protection, and national market system development. The Act also specifies that the Commission shall not grant any application if it unreasonably impairs a dealer's ability to solicit or effect transactions in a security for its own account, or unreasonably restricts competition among dealers. Additionally, a conforming amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is made to clarify the Commission's authority in this regard. The curr_chunk is about the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States, who is also the President of the Senate.
